page.title: 10Quicksands, Tidal Bore
page.content: The Kent Estuary is most unstable; wide, shallow and sandy. The river Kent, rising 25 miles away in the mountains of the Lake District is quickly affected by heavy rainfall. Consequently its channel constantly changes, both in depth and direction; its steep sides varying from a few inches to several feet. This produces hazardous conditions for visitors who venture to wade or swim in the estuary. The resultant{quicksands}are a source of real danger, both to visitors and to local residents. Warning signboards are erected at strategic points. The large basin of Morecambe Bay results in a{tidal bore}in the Kent Estuary. It occurs approximately two hours before high tide and can be very spectacular. A warning siren is sounded at Arnside and Sandside.
